bib_record.title: -excitation functions of (n,t) reactions on Al-27, Co-59, and Nb-93.

free_txt: experimental site and first two authors
third author
.Results compared with excitation functions
obtained from Hauser-Feshbach calculations. Good
agreement only for Al. For the other two isotopes
calculated cross sections were too low.
.Neutron scatter from target cooling water and
from aluminium capsule estimated using Monte-Carlo
calculations, neglecting multiple scattering.
4 to 6% of neutrons were calculated to have
energies outside the range of the unscattered flux.
.Detector efficiencies.
gas phase tritium activity
gamma activity of internal standards used
for neutron flux determination
proton recoil telescope to monitor
neutron flux.
systematic error in tritium activity
measurements
error in tritium extraction efficiency
systematic error in gamma activity
measurements
total uncorrelated error, computed from
quadratic sum of typical values for the
random part of the counting errors.
water-cooled Ti(T) layer about 2mg/cm2 thick
on a 0.3 mm silver backing. Van der Graaff generated
3 MeV deuterons at a current of 50 microamps.
compact hemispherical geometry of three
or four sample segments around the neutron
source. Each segment covered an angular
range with corresponding incident neutron energy
range. Sample enclosed in aluminium capsule to
prevent contamination with tritium from neutron
source.
.Samples irradiated for about 50 hours.
.After irradiation the accumulated tritium was
separated by vacuum extraction in hydrogen atmosphere,
and the activity measured by low level beta minus
anticoincidence counting in the gas phase.
.Gas counting system efficiency determined by using
tritium gas standards.
.Neutron flux, averaged over each segment, was
measured using internal standards based on
gamma active isotopes produced by the irradiation.
gamma activity measured with Ge(Li) detectors.
.Neutron flux measurements checked using an external
proton recoil telescope in 130 degree direction
80 cm from neutron source, and activity measurements
of an external piece of cobalt at zero degrees 25 cm
from source. These techniques were less accurate
because geometry of system was not well known.
.Data taken from private comm.
